#COVID19 has made even clearer what’s always been true: 

1. Every worker supporting our students should be able to take care of their own family. 

2. Ensuring all workers have access to family and medical leave is crucial to keeping our families and our communities safe.

That’s why @SenDuckworth and I introduced bipartisan legislation to ensure ALL education professionals have access to family and medical leave. 

Our ESP #FamilyLeave Act is a small but critical step toward giving school employees the support they deserve.

During #AEW2020, we’ve got to acknowledge the gap in federal law that means many of the workers we entrust to feed, transport, and teach our students are unable to access basic leave benefits without risk of losing their job. 

This is wrong and we must do better.

#EducationSupportProfessionalsDay is an opportunity to thank: 

Classroom aids 

Bus drivers 

Janitorial staff 

Social workers

Cafeteria and maintenance workers
 
All of whom have continued to work tirelessly to support our students through this pandemic.

I was a leader in advocating for Venezuelan freedom — and as an immigrant, my story is the Miami story.

Now more than ever, Congress needs to pass a comprehensive COVID relief bill that provides robust funding for our nation’s public schools and higher education institutions, so these selfless educators are not left behind.

He changed my life. And small acts of kindness like that are happening every single day during this pandemic.

By tutors, teachers and school staff teaching kids at home.

By those risking their health on the front lines without a COVID-19 vaccine teaching kids in person.

“Aw kids, I’m so sorry I kept you working here so late. Here’s $10, go to Taco Bell, it’s 2 for 99 cents—get something to eat before you go home.”

As teenagers, we didn't see it then. But I do now. With his teacher's salary, he was feeding the poorest of us & helping us get by.

When I was in high school, my family relied on food stamps. But sometimes, those food stamps wouldn't last through the week.

Luckily for me, sometimes my English teacher would keep a bunch of us after school—and after a while he’d reach into his own pockets and say:

I wouldn't be where I am today without my teachers.

This #AmericanEducationWeek and throughout COVID-19, I see that same selfless kindness in our educators, social workers, support staff and parents who are working overtime to help students navigate online learning.

Comparing COVID-19 infection rates by race without also taking age into consideration is like comparing apples and oranges. We need the @CDCgov to adjust its racial mortality data for age so we can more accurately inform the public and take action to fight this pandemic.

We know COVID-19 racial disparities exist. But the numbers are even more alarming because the median age of white Americans is 9-22 years older than Black, Latinx, and multi-ethnic groups. In other words: young people of color may be a lot more likely to be dying from COVID.

I fought to get @HHSgov and @CDCgov to release the racial demographic data that show communities of color have been hit hardest by COVID-19. But the data aren't telling the whole story. The Promoting Access to Tribal Health, Wellbeing, and Youth Safety Act, co-sponsored by @SenFeinstein @SenatorTester @MartinHeinrich @SenWarren, would create a new @USDOT program to deploy infrastructure investments that improve public safety and health in Tribal communities.

According to @CDCgov, the number one cause of death of American Indians and Alaska Natives between the ages of one and 44 is vehicle-related unintentional injury.

Inadequate pedestrian infrastructure puts lives at risk. This transportation crisis is also a public health crisis.

In many Native American communities, run-down roads are not merely an inconvenience—they create an obstacle for daily life, making it harder to get healthy groceries, arrive safely to school or find new employment opportunities.

While we wait for a final vaccine approval, we must remain smart, protect the most vulnerable in our communities, and be responsible.

This is about saving lives. It's about supporting our healthcare frontline heroes. It's about protecting Montana jobs & workers and rebuilding our economy. It's about American innovation. It's about restoring hope. It's about restoring normalcy into our way of life.

While this was a blind trial, I have since tested positive for COVID-19 antibodies. My goal is to help build confidence and trust for Montanans and the American people wondering if they should take the vaccine when it is approved.
